q1.value: A series of surveys, including: Online victim selection, coworker treatment, and broker selection

q3.value: These are three separate studies. Online victim selection and coworker treatment will be on the same sample (i.e., MTurk and/or students). Broker selection will be collected on a LinkedIN forum.

q4.value:
Study 1: Online victim selection: We predict that each Dark Triad trait will indicate a high likelihood of willingness to attack an elderly target with a cyber attack. However, when forced to choose between elderly and non-elderly, we predict that Machiavellian individuals will especially select elderly, while Narcissistic and psychopathic individuals will gravitate towards those with more money.

Study 2: coworker treatment: We predict that all three Dark Triad traits will correlate with poor coworker treatment when the coworker is a short-term coworker. However, ONLY Machiavellianism will improve their treatment of a coworker when it is a long-term coworker.

Study 3: Broker selection: We have generated statements that resemble Mach, psychopathic, narcissistic, and low Dark Triad brokers. We predict that individuals will be most satisfied with the broker who resembles a Machiavellian. WE may also explore the interaction between how much money they've made and Machiavellianism in predicting satisfaction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Qualtrics survey platform handles random assignment.

question.value:
Note we are pre-registering three studies at a time here. Two observational, one experimental (straight up survey). 

The cyber attack target study is just observational, as is the broker choice LinkedIN study. 

Co-worker treatment is experimental. They will simply receive a long-term coworker hypothetical description, or a short-term coworker hypothetical description.

q14.value:
We will collect no more than 220 from MTurk due to money constraints. However, in the LInkedIN study, we will run for 1 month or up to 300 people, whichever comes first.

We conducted a power analysis and for all three studies, given the design, 173 was needed for the two observational studies to reach minimum power and 211 is needed for the experiment. Thus, we will collect a minimum of 220 for all studies.

q15.value: 220 for the cyber and coworker study, 300 (or one month of running) for the broker choice linked in study.

question.value: This is not relevant for the two observational studies. WE will have three conditions for the coworker study (longterm, shortterm, and control, which has no mention of length)

Dark Triad will be the Short Dark Triad (Jones & Paulhus, 2014) will be used for the cyber target study AND the coworker study.

In the coworker study we ask 7 interpersonal deviance questions from Bennett & Robinson 2000. We also include a few questions about citizenship behavior, and two questions about ridiculing and mocking others WITH a coworker (not directed at their coworker), these will constitute three separate scales. 

In the linkedin study, we have two questions after each description that will be merged into a composite.

We w
Short Dark Triad will be properly coded and merged into three separate indices of Mach, psyc, and narc.

For the experiment (coworkers) we will dummy code the experimental variable with the control condition as the reference group. We will then run THREE SEPARATE regressions for each Dark Triad trait (e.g., Mach, dum1, dum2, mach*dum1, mach*dum2), for exploratory purposes, we may include all Dark Triad traits with all interactions as well. WE may also explore gender differences, given that Mach has recently revealed interesting interactions with gender.

For the broker selection LInkedIN STudy, we will run basic correlations and regressions. For example, we will correlate satisfaction with each dv of broker description, and will also regress satisfaction on the four broker descriptions. Exploratory wise, we may also compute interactions with broker description and money made to predict satisfaction. We may also examine money made on broker description.

For the cyber target study, we will use correlation and regression. We may use ordinal regression for the variable that is forced choice (pick 4 out of 8 targets).

q20.value: Scales will be recoded appropriately according to the scale definitions

q22.value: DUration of survey will be used as described previously

q24.value: gender, age, and SES may be explored

attributes.title: Predicting Self-Exclusion from Daily Fantasy Sports

summary.value: This is a pre-registration for the study "Predicting Self-Exclusion from Daily Fantasy Sports". The attached pre-registration provides detailed information about the data set, sample, design, and analytic plans for this study. The study is a secondary data analysis. The authors have analyzed some of these data for previous publications and manuscripts in preparation, as detailed in this pre-registration, but have not yet analyzed any data for two of the three cohorts to be sampled and have not analyzed any data related to self-exclusion.

q1.value: Motivations Associated with Enacting Positive and Negative Social Control Strategies

q3.value: Although research has shown that people use social control strategies to deliberately modify their close relationship partners' health behaviors (e.g., Craddock, vanDellen, Novak, & Ranby, 2015), few studies have examined people's motivations for using different social control strategies. The current research offers a first examination of the motivations associated with using positive and negative social control strategies.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1) The motivation “I used this behavior because I thought [initials] would respond positively (e.g., be appreciative)” is positively related to the provision of positive social control strategies

Hypothesis 2) The motivation “I used this behavior because [initials] asked me to use this behavior to help them change their health behavior” is positively related to the provision of positive social control strategies 

Hypothesis 3) The motivation “I used this behavior because I felt negative emotions (e.g., anger, frustration, embarrassment) about [initials]’s health behavior” is positively related to the provision of negative social control strategies  

Hypothesis 4) The motivation “I used this behavior because I felt powerless to change [initials]’s health behavior” is positively related to the provision of negative social control strategies  

Hypothesis 5) The motivation “My previous attempts to change [initials]’s health behavior were ineffective” is positively related to the provision of negative social control strategies

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated measures with a mixed design

q9.value: The order in which participants view the positive and negative strategies lists is random (randomly assigned via Qualtrics randomization).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1.	Population: 200 individuals from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (English speaking) will be enrolled in the study and 200 individuals from Clickworker (German speaking) will be enrolled in the study.
2.	Recruitment Efforts: Participants will be recruited using study postings on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk and Clickworker. 
3.	Payment for Participation: Participants will be compensated $1.25 / 1.25 Swiss Franc for participation.
4.	Eligibility Requirements: To be included in this study, individuals must be at least 18 years old, pass a CAPTCHA, must be native speakers of English (for Mturk) or German (for Clickworker), must be currently trying to influence the health behavior of someone close to them, or have tried to influence in the past 6 months the health behavior of someone close to them.
5.	Study Timeline: The entire process, from collecting data to analyzing data, will take approximately 4 months.

q13.value: 400 individuals (n = 200 from Mturk and n = 200 from Clickworker)

q14.value: According to G*Power, a sample size of n = 216 will enable us to detect a small effect (f = .10) at > 95% power with 2 groups. We doubled the sample size in order to get more qualitative, (exploratory) data (which will inform future studies).

q15.value: The sample size was pre-determined based on power analysis, interest in collecting additional qualitative data, and funding available.

question.value: N/A

1.	Social control strategies used by participants to change a close other’s health behavior: selected / not selected
2.	Social control strategy ranking: order of social control strategies used, from most frequent (1) to least frequent (up to 20)
3.	Social control motivations: Participants’ agreement with different motivations for using positive or negative social control strategies
4.	Process of social control interactions: open-ended responses from participants about the experiences of trying to change or influence their close other’s health behavior
5.	Moderators: Participants’ subjective closeness with their close other, relationship quality

1.	Social control strategies used (overall): The social control strategies selected by participants will be summed
a.	Positive social control strategies used: The positive social control strategies selected by participants will be summed
b.	Negative social control strategies used: The negative social control strategies selected by participants will be summed
2.	Relationship quality (Relationship Assessment Scale): Each item will be averaged together to form a composite relationship quality score (higher scores = better relationship quality).

1.	Hypothesis 1
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictor: Score for item: I used this behavior because I thought [initials] would respond positively (e.g., be appreciative) 
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies 
2.	Hypothesis 2
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictor: Score for item: I used this behavior because [initials] asked me to use this behavior to help them change their health behavior 
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies 
3.	Hypothesis 3
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictor: Score for item: I used this behavior because I felt negative emotions (e.g., anger, frustration, embarrassment) about [initials]’s health behavior 
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies 
4.	Hypothesis 4
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictor: Score for item: I used this behavior because I felt powerless to change [initials]’s health behavior 
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies
5.	Hypothesis 5
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictor: Score for item: My previous attempts to change [initials]’s health behavior were ineffective 
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies

q20.value: If necessary (i.e. strongly skewed measures) we will use appropriate transformations.

q21.value: We will be using p-values to draw inferences (using a significance level of p = .05).

q22.value: We will exclude participants who indicate they were extremely distracted, did not complete the survey in one sitting, or were highly inattentive.

q23.value: At the level of computing scales, missing data will be coded as (999) and will be omitted.

q24.value:
1.	Question: How are the following motivations associated with provision of positive social control strategies? a) I used this behavior because I thought it would be effective in changing [initials]’s health behavior b) I felt afraid of the health consequences of [initials]’s health behavior c) I used this behavior because I find it effective when someone uses this behavior to change my own health behavior
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item)
c.	Outcome: Positive social control strategies
2.	Question: Are different motivations associated with the provision of positive social control strategies for different relationship partners? 
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship type between participant and target, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship type
c.	Outcome: Positive social control strategies
3.	Question: Are different motivations associated with the provision of negative social control strategies for different relationship partners?
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship type between participant and target, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship type
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies
4.	Question: Does relationship length moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of positive social control strategies?
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship length, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship length
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies
5.	Question: Does relationship length moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of negative social control strategies?
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship length, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship length
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies

6.	Question: Does relationship quality moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of positive social control strategies? 
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship quality, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship quality
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies
7.	Question: Does relationship quality moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of negative social control strategies? 
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), relationship quality, and the interaction between motivation score and relationship quality
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies
8.	Question: Does subjective closeness moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of positive social control strategies? 
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), subjective closeness, and the interaction between motivation score and subjective closeness
c.	Outcome: Positive control strategies
9.	Question: Does subjective closeness moderate the associations between motivations and the provision of negative social control strategies? 
a.	Model: Multilevel modeling
b.	Predictors: Score for each motivation item (separate model for each motivation item), subjective closeness, and the interaction between motivation score and subjective closeness
c.	Outcome: Negative control strategies
10.	Question: Are there cultural differences in any of the confirmatory or exploratory tests?
a.	Models: Run the previously defined models but include language (English vs. German) as a covariate

q25.value:
Additional Coding:
•	Other Social Control Strategies. For participants who indicate they did not use any of the listed behaviors to try to change their close other’s health behavior, we will code the following open-ended responses: 
o	Item: Please describe behaviors you have used to change [initials]’s health behavior. 
•	Other Motivations. Participants also indicate any other reasons / motivations for using different social control strategies. These will be coded to identify additional, distinct motivations for using social control. 
•	Process of Interactions. Participants will indicate when they first started using social control and, if their social control strategies changed over time, how they changed and why they changed. These open-ended responses will be coded for the following:
o	Trigger of social control use. What triggered participants’ initial use of social control?
o	Trigger of social control strategy shift. What triggered participants to switch their use of social control?

attributes.title: Pathways to Risk: An Examination of Friend and Romantic Partner Substance Use as Mediators of Genetic Predisposition for Externalizing Behaviors on Alcohol Use

q1.value: Pathways to Risk: An Examination of Friend and Romantic Partner Substance Use as Mediators of Genetic Predisposition for Externalizing Behaviors on Alcohol Outcomes

q3.value: The aim of the present study is to examine whether selection into relationships with friends and romantic partners who use substances 1) mediates and 2) moderates the association between genetic propensity for externalizing behaviors, measured via polygenic scores, and alcohol outcomes (alcohol use, alcohol problems, binge drinking) among college students.

q4.value:
1) It is hypothesized that friend and romantic partner substance use will partially mediate the association between genetic propensity for externalizing and alcohol outcomes. Individuals with higher polygenic scores as well as individuals who associate with friends and partners with higher levels of substance use will report higher levels of alcohol use, more alcohol problems, and more frequent binge drinking themselves. Individuals with higher polygenic scores for externalizing will be more likely to associate with friends and romantic partners with higher levels of substance use.

question.value:
Externalizing polygenic risk score.
I will calculate genome-wide polygenic risk scores (GPS) using prioritized single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) identified in an independent genome-wide association study (GWAS) of externalizing behavior from the Externalizing Consortium GWAS of externalizing behaviors (Dick et al., 2019). Polygenic scores for this study will be derived using the PLINK 1.9 clump and score procedures (Chang et al., 2015; Purcell et al., 2007). Scores are calculated by multiplying the number of effect-coded alleles by the per-allele SNP effect (beta). The values of all prioritized alleles are then summed to create the polygenic score, with higher polygenic scores indicating greater predisposition for externalizing behaviors. Clumping procedures ensure that SNPs included in the GPS are relatively independent. Clumping will be performed using linkage disequilibrium (LD) patterns observed in the 1000 Genome Phase 3 sample with 500kb physical distance and an LD threshold of r2 less than or equal to 0.25 (The 1000 Genomes Project Consortium, 2015). I will calculate GPS in the Spit for Science sample using several p-value thresholds (e.g., p less than .0001, p less than 0.001, p less than 0.01, p less than 0.10, p less than 0.20, p less than 0.30, p less than 0.40, p less than 0.50). The GPS calculated from the p-value threshold with the strongest association with alcohol use behaviors in the Spit for Science sample will be selected for use in the proposed models.

Multi-ethnic GPS.
Due to variation in allele frequency for different ancestry groups (Peterson et al., 2019), all analyses will be run separately by ancestral group. The Externalizing GWAS discovery sample was limited to individuals of European ancestry; thus, I will create multi-ancestry GPS (MultiPRS; Marquez-Luna et al., 2017). This approach combines the GPS based on large and mostly European ancestry samples with GPS  from each of the ancestral groups using a 10-fold cross-validation. For the AA sample, a 10-fold cross-validation is used. These GPS  are then weighted and combined along with ancestry PCs to estimate multi-ancestry GPS for each minority ancestral sample. 

Ancestry Principal Components.
Ancestry principal components (PCs) account for variation in allele frequency across different population structures. They are computed PCA using EIGENSOFT and SmartPCA (Patterson, Price, & Reich, 2006; Price et al., 2006). Regions of high LD will be excluded using PLINK 1.9, so as to ensure that SNPs are relatively independent. The 1000 Genome Project phase 3 reference panel will be used to calculate ancestry PCs.

Alcohol use.
Alcohol use was measured at baseline and follow-up as the estimated grams of ethanol consumed per month based on participants’ self-reported quantity and frequency of drinking at baseline and each follow-up (see Salvatore et al., 2016 for additional details).

Alcohol problems.
Alcohol problems were assessed at baseline and follow-up via 15 items adapted from the Semi-Structured Assessment for the Genetics of Alcoholism (SSAGA; Bucholz et al., 1994). Items from the SSAGA correspond to the 11 alcohol use disorder criteria based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition. I will create sum scores based on the total number of symptoms endorsed by participants.

Binge drinking.
Binge drinking frequency was assessed separately for men and women. Male participants reported how often they consumed five or more drinks in a single sitting (considered about a 2 hour period); female participants  reported how often they consumed four or more drinks in a single sitting.

Friend substance use.
At each follow-up, friend substance use was measured based on how many college friends each participant perceived engaged in each of the following behaviors: drinks alcohol, gets drunk, and has a problem with alcohol (like hangovers, fights, accidents), and smokes cigarettes. College friends were defined as “people who you would have seen regularly and spent time with in school and outside of school” since starting college. Participants responded to each of the three stems using a Likert-type scale with response options ranging from “none of my friends” (1) to “all of my friends” (5).

Romantic partner substance use.
At each follow-up, participants in a relationship for three months or longer indicated how often they perceive their partner engaged in each of the following behaviors: drinks alcohol, has a problem with alcohol (like hangovers, fights, accidents), and smokes cigarettes. Participants responded to each of the three stems with a Likert-type scale with response options ranging from “never” (1) to “every day” (5). 

Covariates.
-Sex was a single self-report item, measured at baseline. It will be coded as male (0) or female (1).
-Age was a single self-report item, be measured in years at baseline.
-Race/ethnicity was a self-report item, measured at baseline. Race/ethnicity will be collapsed into the four largest groups: White, African American/Black, Asian, Hispanic/Latino. The fifth group will be comprised of participants who identify as more than once race/ethnicity or any other race/ethnicity. Participants who reported their race/ethnicity as unknown or chose not to answer will be categorized as missing.
-Cohort will also be included as a covariate, as previous analyses have indicated differences in alcohol use across cohorts.
-Genotyping batch will be included as a covariate.
-Ancestral principle components will be included to control for population stratification (Peterson et al., 2017).

Friend substance use - At each follow-up, friend substance use was measured based on how many college friends each participant perceived engaged in each of the following behaviors: drinks alcohol, gets drunk, and has a problem with alcohol (like hangovers, fights, accidents), and smokes cigarettes. College friends were defined as “people who you would have seen regularly and spent time with in school and outside of school” since starting college. Participants responded to each of the three stems using a Likert-type scale with response options ranging from “none of my friends” (1) to “all of my friends” (5). A composite score from the sum of endorsed items will be calculated, with higher totals indicating higher levels of friend substance use (Kendler et al., 2015).

Romantic partner substance use - At each follow-up, participants in a relationship for three months or longer indicated how often they perceived their partner engaged in each of the following behaviors: drinks alcohol, has a problem with alcohol (like hangovers, fights, accidents), and smokes cigarettes. Participants responded to each of the three stems with a Likert-type scale with response options ranging from “never” (1) to “every day” (5). A composite score from the average of the endorsed items will be calculated. Higher scores will indicate higher levels of partner substance use (Kendler et al., 2015).

Alcohol problems.
Alcohol problems were assessed at baseline and follow-up via 15 items adapted from the Semi-Structured Assessment for the Genetics of Alcoholism (SSAGA; Bucholz et al., 1994). Items from the SSAGA correspond to the 11 alcohol use disorder criteria based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition. I will create sum scores based on the total number of symptoms endorsed by participants.

question.value:
Data from the Spit for Science project will be used in the present study. The Spit for Science project is a university-wide initiative at a large, urban four-year university focused on college students’ substance use and behavioral health outcomes. The Spit for Science project launched in fall 2011 and new cohorts of freshmen were recruited in 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2017, resulting in five cohorts as of fall 2018. All incoming freshmen over age 18 were invited to participate in the Spit for Science survey and were given the opportunity to provide saliva samples. DNA was then extracted from the saliva samples to generate genome-wide data. Participants were invited to complete follow-up surveys every subsequent spring semester until graduating.

In order to be included in the present study, participants must have completed at least one follow-up survey and provided genetic data.

To examine whether genetic predisposition for externalizing behavior influences selection into relationships with friends and romantic partners to predict alcohol outcomes, I will use structural equation modeling to capitalize on the longitudinal data available in the sample. I will also examine whether friends' and romantic partners' substance use moderates the association between genetic predisposition and alcohol outcomes (alcohol consumption, alcohol problems, and binge drinking).

question.value:
Prior to data analysis, all variables will be examined to ensure they meet appropriate assumptions and to identify any outliers. I will calculate means, standard deviations, skewness, and kurtosis for all continuous variables and frequency distributions for all categorical variables. It is anticipated that alcohol use and alcohol problems will be natural log-transformed after adding a constant of one to adjust for positive skew while retaining individuals who drank zero grams of ethanol and reported no problems with alcohol. Similar procedures will be employed for other variables that demonstrate skewness or kurtosis. After preliminary analyses, I will run descriptive statistics and zero-order correlations to characterize the associations between all key study variables. 

The goal of the present study is to examine whether 1) genetic predisposition for externalizing behavior influences selection into relationships with friends and romantic partners to predict alcohol outcomes, and 2) whether friends' and romantic partners' substance use moderates the association between genetic predisposition and alcohol outcomes. Using the lavaan package in R, I will employ structural equation modeling within a multilevel model approach to capitalize on the longitudinal data available in the sample. Externalizing polygenic scores will be included as my main predictor. Friend substance use and romantic partner substance use at the first follow-up will each be included as mediators, controlling for alcohol outcomes at the first follow-up. Alcohol outcomes at the second follow-up will serve as my outcome variable, controlling for friend and romantic partner substance use at the second follow-up. Thus, I will be able to establish a temporal order to examine my research aim.

Any data that does not meet the following inclusion criteria will be excluded. attributes.title: Motivations for the use of intimate partner aggression
attributes.description: This empirical study looks at relationships between intimate partner aggression (IPA) and the motivations for it’s use and the consequences resulting from it’s use.

q1.value: Motivations for the use of intimate partner aggression

q3.value:
This research looks at relationships between intimate partner aggression (IPA) and the motivations for its use and the consequences resulting from its use. Specifically, we aim to explore the relationships between self-reported acts of aggression with controlling and general aggression motivations for IPA, and to explore the relationships between experiencing these same self-reported acts and a variety of outcomes. 
The most common way of assessing control in intimate relationships is with measures of frequency of non-physical controlling behaviours, such as restricting access to friends and family members. However, the enaction of these behaviours have become conflated with the motivation of the perpetrator; the motive of control is thereby assumed. 
The first aim of the current study is to investigate whether controlling motives are distinctly related to a specific subset of IPA behavioural acts.
There is little consensus in the literature as to whether control should be defined as the motivation of the perpetrator or in relation to the negative outcomes for victims (Hamberger, Larsen, & Lehrner, 2017). The second aim of this study is therefore to explore the possibility that victim experiences of control are distinctly related to a specific subset of IPA behavioural acts. 
There is also considerable disagreement within the IPA literature in relation to gender and controlling behaviour. The third aim of this study is therefore to investigate if there are gender differences in the types of IPA acts used, the motivations for its use, and the outcomes for the victim, or if these are the same for men and women. 
For a full background and rationale of the study, please refer to the file labelled Research Plan - Revised 20191205

q4.value:
Aim 1
Ha0: Control motives are equally associated with the perpetration of Eclectic Aggression, Direct Psychological Aggression, and Monitoring Acts as general aggression motives.
Ha1: Control motives are more strongly associated with the perpetration of Eclectic Aggression, Direct Psychological Aggression, and Monitoring Acts than general aggression motives. 
Aim 2
Hb0: Feeling controlled is equally associated with experiencing Eclectic Aggression, Direct Psychological Aggression, and Monitoring Acts as other outcomes associated with experiencing IPA.  
Hb1: Feeling controlled is more strongly associated with experiencing Eclectic Aggression, Direct Psychological Aggression, and Monitoring Acts than other outcomes associated with experiencing IPA.

question.value:
We will recruit adult participants who are users of Amazon's Mechanical Turk 
(MTurk) exclusively for completion of online based tasks and surveys. Users of this service sign up for the service voluntarily and select to complete tasks or surveys that are advertised on this service at their discretion. 
The project will be advertised on MTurk as a "Research survey about aggression in your current or a recent relationship” and available to users from North America (US and Canada). Users who accept the described task will be given a link directing them to the online 
survey site (Qualtrics) to complete the survey. Participants will need to be English speaking, must be at least 18 years old, and have been in an intimate/ dating relationship lasting at least one month in the last 12 months. Participants will be paid $1.20 (USD). Upon completing the survey on the Qualtrics survey site, they will be given a confirmation code to enter into the MTurk site, which is used by the researchers to identify participants for reimbursement.
	Participants will be excluded from analyses should they fail to meet the criteria outlined above or fail to provide their consent to participate. Participant’s data will also be excluded if they fail to complete 90% of the survey. Participants with less than 10% of missing data will have their responses imputed using Expectation Maximisation. As two of the hypotheses directly investigate binary gender differences, participants who identify as non-binary, will be excluded from the analyses. Participants will also be excluded if they show clear patterns of non-responding or have unreasonably quick completion times. Due to the design of the survey, the completion times will be highly variable and thus, a cut-off for response times cannot be determined a priori. A post-hoc inspection of the sample distribution of time will therefore be conducted to identify those participants who completed the survey unfeasibly quickly.

question.value:
Questions relating to perpetrated behavioural acts are items derived from a previous study conducted by the authors. These items were each endorsed by more than 20% of the participants in this study. The types of behaviours include physical and psychological aggression and monitoring behaviours. Each time participants in the current study indicate they have carried out one of the aggressive behaviours, a list of possible motivations for aggressive behaviour appears. The motives for the use of the aggressive acts are informed by theories of general aggression and a review of the qualitative literature on the motivations for the use of IPA. 
Questions relating to experiences of IPA are the same behavioural acts used to measure perpetration that have been duplicated and re-worded to form response category pairs. Each time participants indicate they have experienced one of the aggressive behaviours, a list of possible outcomes for aggressive behaviour appears. The outcomes are based upon the work of Evan Stark (2006, 2007), the Motivations and Effects Questionnaire (MEQ: Follingstad et al., 1991), and the WEB (Smith et al., 1995). 
Social desirability bias will be assessed using the Balanced Inventory of Desirable Responding Short Form (BIDR-16: Paulhus, 1991). 
Refer to file labelled Appendix B Questionnaire for the complete survey

We will conduct Bayesian exploratory factor analysis (BEFA) using the R package ‘BayesFM’ to factor analyse the items. This method will be employed for perpetrated and experienced behaviours. 
A Markov Chain Monte Carlo simulation using the R package ‘bindata’ will be conducted to determine the appropriate sample size to produce reliable factorial solutions. 
The R package, ‘blavaan’ will be used to conduct Bayesian structural equation modelling. Log-Bayes factors will be used to determine the relative strength of the evidence for the alternative hypotheses, with a factor less than or greater than one, as suggested by Raftery (1995), indicating substantial evidence for these. 
A perpetrated behaviour model (Figure 1 in Research Plan 20191205) and an experienced behaviour model (Figure 2 in Research Plan 20191205) will be produced, and it will be determined whether these are moderated by gender. If this model fails to converge due to the complexity of the model, a model comparison design using averaged non-latent variables based on the underlying structure identified by the BEFA will be employed.

registration_responses.q1: Motivations for the use of intimate partner aggression
registration_responses.q3:
This research looks at relationships between intimate partner aggression (IPA) and the motivations for its use and the consequences resulting from its use. Specifically, we aim to explore the relationships between self-reported acts of aggression with controlling and general aggression motivations for IPA, and to explore the relationships between experiencing these same self-reported acts and a variety of outcomes. 
The most common way of assessing control in intimate relationships is with measures of frequency of non-physical controlling behaviours, such as restricting access to friends and family members. However, the enaction of these behaviours have become conflated with the motivation of the perpetrator; the motive of control is thereby assumed. 
The first aim of the current study is to investigate whether controlling motives are distinctly related to a specific subset of IPA behavioural acts.
There is little consensus in the literature as to whether control should be defined as the motivation of the perpetrator or in relation to the negative outcomes for victims (Hamberger, Larsen, & Lehrner, 2017). The second aim of this study is therefore to explore the possibility that victim experiences of control are distinctly related to a specific subset of IPA behavioural acts. 
There is also considerable disagreement within the IPA literature in relation to gender and controlling behaviour. The third aim of this study is therefore to investigate if there are gender differences in the types of IPA acts used, the motivations for its use, and the outcomes for the victim, or if these are the same for men and women. 
For a full background and rationale of the study, please refer to the file labelled Research Plan - Revised 20191205

attributes.title: Examining self-reported motivations for physical and psychological intimate partner aggression: A systematic review

q1.value: Examining self-reported motivations for physical and psychological intimate partner aggression: A systematic review

3.	Does the quality of research impact the effect sizes of motivations for perpetration of IPA?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This research systematically reviews the empirical literature on self-reported motivations for the use of physical and psychological intimate partner aggression (IPA).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
PsycINFO, Sage Journals and Web of Science databases were searched in July 2019. The key words used in the search were: "intimate partner violence" OR "domestic violence" AND intent* OR motiv*. The search in PsycINFO was limited to the abstracts of quantitative, journal articles, published in English. No date restriction was imposed. This resulted in 242 articles. The search in Sage Journals was limited to the abstracts of journal articles date with no date restriction, resulting in 212 articles. The search in Web of Science was unrestricted by date but limited to articles published in English. The search terms were searched for in the titles of the journals as the abstract was not available as a field code on this database. This search resulted in 35 articles. Overall, the database search identified 489 articles relating to motivations for the use of physical and/ or psychological IPA. 
A request was made via blog post to the Association of Domestic Violence Intervention Providers for unpublished data. However, this did not yield any further studies. Langhinrichsen-Rohling et al conducted a systematic review of motivations for the use of physical aggression in intimate relationships in 2012. The 74 studies included in their review were included in the current review due to their highly relevant nature. Two additional records were identified by the authors, resulting in a total of 76 additional resources. 
The focus of this review was on studies investigating self-reported motivations for physical and psychological aggression. These studies had to be quantitative, use self-reported measures of aggression and motivations for the use of this aggression, and a continuous/ ordinal measure of aggression. 
This study defined motivation or motives as a preceding act or psychological or physiological state which influences an individual’s behaviour. Motives are not considered to be personality characteristics (e.g., attachment style, impulsivity) or risk factors for IPA (e.g., substance use, attitudes towards violence).
Examples of reasons why studies were excluded included a qualitative study design, a focus on risk factors or personality characteristics as opposed to motivations for aggression, the use of hypothetical scenarios (e.g., vignettes), and motivations that were inferred by the victim or by researcher (i.e., were not self-report). 
The review will be conducted in line with the PRISMA guidelines (Moher et al., 2009), and be informed by the AMSTAR systematic review quality guide (Shea et al., 2009). Refer to Figure 1 in the Research Plan for the PRISMA flow diagram, which includes information regarding the identification, screening and exclusion and inclusion of studies. 
Each study included in the review will be assessed according to quality criteria based on the Mixed Methods Appraisal Tool (Version 2018; Hong et al.).

q13.value: 24 studies are included in the qualitative synthesis.

question.value:
This study defined motivation or motives as a preceding act or psychological or physiological state which influences an individual’s behaviour. Motives are not considered to be personality characteristics (e.g., attachment style, impulsivity) or risk factors for IPA (e.g., substance use, attitudes towards violence).
This study defined intimate partner aggression (IPA) as "any form of aggression used against a current or past intimate partner of any gender or relationship status" (Dixon & Graham-Kevan, 2011)

Comprehensive Meta Analysis software will be used to determine the which motivations for IPA have the largest effect sizes (Research Question 2) and to conduct a sensitivity analysis (Research Question 3). In the event an insufficient amount of data is available, a summary of effect sizes will be provided.

attributes.title: Increased false-alarms with losses
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

question2a.value: IV: Valence (loss: negative numbers, gain: positive numbers) – within-subject variable.

question2b.value:
False-alarms rate: calculated as the number of items participants incorrectly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test, although it was not) divided by the number of “new” items (i.e., in the memory task – items that were not seen before in the gambling task). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses.
Hits rate: calculated as the number of items participants correctly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants correctly report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test) divided by the number of “old” items (i.e., four items). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses
Both rates range 0 to 1.

question3b.value: Moderator: Filler task (Anagrams: an anagram task will be performed between the gambling and recognition tasks, None: Participants will perform the recognition task right after the gambling task) – between-subject variable.

question10b.value:
The experiment will be programmed using the oTree platform (Chen, Schonger, & Wickens, 2016). The gambling task involves making 64 repeated selections between two virtual buttons labeled “Bet” and “Skip”. Upon choosing either button, the payoff for the given trial will be presented above the two buttons. Choosing “Bet” implies that the payoff is realized (i.e., added to the participants’ tally which determined their take-home amount), while choosing “Skip” implied that the payoff is  not realized. Following each selection, payoffs are drawn from one of the following two sets: [2, 8, 51, 87, -3, -6, -28, -96], or [-2, -8, -51, -87, 3, 6, 28, 96]. These two sets are identical with the exception that gains in one sets are converted to losses in the other and vice versa. The expected value of the lottery is either slightly negative (set 1) or positive (set 2). Before beginning the task each participant is randomly assigned to one of the two sets, and this assignment remains constant throughout the task. Each item is presented eight times throughout the gambling task in random order (i.e., payoff sets presented above are duplicated eight times for a total of 64 items, and then randomly shuffled for each participant).
Participants will receive no prior information about the payoff distributions or the number of trials. They are told that their task is to choose “Bet” or “Skip” on each trial, and that “Bet” outcomes are added to or subtracted from their final payoff, while "Skip" outcomes are not. Participants are also informed of the conversion rate for the outcomes (1000 points = $1), and that either way they would not earn more than $2 nor less than $1. Half of the participants will perform a filler task, in which they have two minutes to solve a set of fifteen anagrams. Subsequently, the experiment automatically continues to a surprise recognition task.
In the recognition task participants were presented with 20 numbers, including the 8 outcomes and an additional 12 numbers that were not presented in the gambling task: [17, 26, 4, 18, 9, 38, 92,16,46, 73, 5,7]. They will then be asked to report for each of the  20 numbers if it was (1) presented in the gambling task as a gain, (2) presented in the gambling task as a loss, (3) wasn’t presented at the gambling task at all. All 20 numbers will be presented in the same webpage and a combo-box next to each of the numbers will be used for the report. Their order will be randomized per participant.
Participants will be paid as follows: $1.2 for participation (completing the tasks), extra $0.2 for performing the Anagrams task (i.e., participants in the longer version of the experiment which includes the Anagrams task, will be rewarded with $0.2) and a bonus contingent on their performance as described above.

question4b.value: We restrict participation to individuals who are USA residents and has a 95% approval rate of previous works submitted to MTurk.

question6b.value: Based on the previous studies we ran and financial constraints, we plan to collect 230 participants (the largest sample size out among the three previous studies).

question8b.value:
Exclusion Criteria:
-	Participants who will not complete all 64 trials and the recognition task will not be included in the analysis. 
-	Participant who will fail the attention check (i.e., will not follow the instruction to write “thanks” in the first instructions page) or will fail a CAPTCHA test, will not be able to participate in the experiment (i.e., the experiment will stop and they will not be able to continue).
-	Outliers removal: participants who mark all items as either “old gains” or “old losses” in the recognition task will be removed from all analyses.

question10c.value: If Sphericity in the ANOVA test is violated (Machuly's test), proper DF will be used (e.g., Greenhouse–Geisser)

question5a.value:
Studies of negativity/positivity effects in memory have typically focused on incidental memory of words , sentences, and pictures, or on autobiographic memories (see reviews in Baumeister et al., 2001; O’Keefe & Jensen, 2008). The resulting asymmetries in people’s memory for positives and negatives are illuminating with respect to how people remember ecologically relevant events, but it is not easy to map them to basic asymmetries in perception, attention, and memory. This is the case because external information that is positive or negative is often different in many respects, and these multidimensional differences may confound the basic difference in valence. A case in point is a puzzle in the domain of incidental recognition, initially observed by Ortony, Turner, and Antos (1983). In their study participants read positive and negative affective sentences and were then were asked to recognize them in a surprise test. Even though there was no difference in the number of correctly recognized positive and negative sentences, there were more false alarms for positive than negative sentences. Recently, Alves, Unkelbach,  Burghardt, Koch, Krüger, and Becker (2015) replicated this puzzling phenomenon but also showed that it is driven by greater similarity between positive words than between negative words. This highlights the need for examinations of memories using objectively similar positive and negative events. In the present paper, we examine participants’ memory of positive and negative experienced outcomes to address this issue in the context of the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle.
	Various theories provide qualitative predictions regarding this puzzle. Sedikides and Green (2006; 2009; Sedikides et al., 2016) espoused the view that people prefer to deliberate on and report positive events that are not threatening to one’s self. This account was developed to explain the Pollyanna effect (Boucher & Osgood, 1969), the finding that incidental memory tends to be more accurate for positive than negatives. Yet it does not explain why false alarm rates should be higher positive events. Another relevant  account is the Paradoxical Negative Emotion (PNE) hypothesis of Porter, Taylor, and Brinke (2008) which argues that negative emotions increases susceptibility to misinformation. Direct evidence for this relatively hypothesis was first obtained by Porter, Spencer, and Birt (2003). Participants viewed emotional visual images as stimuli, and were then asked if there was a large animal in the scene. Negative images were associated with an increased susceptibility to misinformation by 40% over positive and neutral images. Similarly, Porter et al. (2008) asked participants whether they could recall 20 ‘‘widely publicized’’ public events that were positively or negatively valanced. Half of the events were actually fictitious. The findings indicated that more than twice as many participants falsely recognized a bogus negative event (90%) compared to a bogus positive event (42%). Note, however, that this account predicts a bias in the opposite direction of the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle, with more false alarms for negatives than positives.
	Porter et al. (2008) explained their findings and the PNE hypothesis as the result of an evolutionary adaptation. They argue that negative events should be recalled better over time than neutral or other emotional events, in order to avoid or deal with them in the future (Porter & Peace, 2007). Given that it is normally adaptive to incorporate relevant information concerning negative events from others deemed trustworthy (the researchers, for example), this leads to an increased positive response bias for negative events. An alternative explanation is based on the findings of a series of studies Paz and colleagues (Schechtman, Laufer, & Paz, 2010; Laufer & Paz, 2012; Resnik, Sobel N, & Paz, 2011). They demonstrated that individuals tend to show more greater generalization for negative cues than for positive cues. For example in Schechtman et al. (2010) participants responded to a tone that was farther away from an aversive conditioned tone, compared to an equivalent rewarding tone. Therefore, participants may have more false alarms for losses due to overgeneralization of cues presented during the recognition task.  
Still, as mentioned above, it could be that Porter et al.’s (2008) findings might be due to specific properties of the selected events, such as dissimilarities between events. Moreover, the discrepancy between the findings of Porter et al. (2008) and the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle suggests that additional evidence needs to be collected. To examine the effect of valence on false alarms in a setting with relatively symmetric objective gains and losses, we used a decisions-from-experience task (Rakow & Newell, 2010; Erev & Haruvy, 2015), in which an individual’s gains and losses are the positive and negative events. Gains and losses were counter-balanced creating an objective symmetry in the distribution of events. In three studies, we found evidence for increased false alarm rates in losses (negative valence stimuli), compared to gains.

question1c.value:
The calculation of both IVs was described in the design section as follows:
False-alarms rate: calculated as the number of items participants incorrectly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test, although it was not) divided by the number of “new” items (i.e., in the memory task – items that were not seen before in the gambling task). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses.
Hits rate: calculated as the number of items participants correctly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants correctly report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test) divided by the number of “old” items (i.e., four items). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses
Both rates range 0 to 1.

question2c.value: We will conduct two mixed-effect ANOVAs, one for each DV (H1: False-alarm rate, H2: Hit rate). The within-subject IV will be valence, and between-subject moderator is the presence of an Anagrams task (yes/no).
