registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: Valence will be manipulated as well as a filler task before the memory task, no need for manipulation check.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
Studies of negativity/positivity effects in memory have typically focused on incidental memory of words , sentences, and pictures, or on autobiographic memories (see reviews in Baumeister et al., 2001; O’Keefe & Jensen, 2008). The resulting asymmetries in people’s memory for positives and negatives are illuminating with respect to how people remember ecologically relevant events, but it is not easy to map them to basic asymmetries in perception, attention, and memory. This is the case because external information that is positive or negative is often different in many respects, and these multidimensional differences may confound the basic difference in valence. A case in point is a puzzle in the domain of incidental recognition, initially observed by Ortony, Turner, and Antos (1983). In their study participants read positive and negative affective sentences and were then were asked to recognize them in a surprise test. Even though there was no difference in the number of correctly recognized positive and negative sentences, there were more false alarms for positive than negative sentences. Recently, Alves, Unkelbach,  Burghardt, Koch, Krüger, and Becker (2015) replicated this puzzling phenomenon but also showed that it is driven by greater similarity between positive words than between negative words. This highlights the need for examinations of memories using objectively similar positive and negative events. In the present paper, we examine participants’ memory of positive and negative experienced outcomes to address this issue in the context of the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle.
	Various theories provide qualitative predictions regarding this puzzle. Sedikides and Green (2006; 2009; Sedikides et al., 2016) espoused the view that people prefer to deliberate on and report positive events that are not threatening to one’s self. This account was developed to explain the Pollyanna effect (Boucher & Osgood, 1969), the finding that incidental memory tends to be more accurate for positive than negatives. Yet it does not explain why false alarm rates should be higher positive events. Another relevant  account is the Paradoxical Negative Emotion (PNE) hypothesis of Porter, Taylor, and Brinke (2008) which argues that negative emotions increases susceptibility to misinformation. Direct evidence for this relatively hypothesis was first obtained by Porter, Spencer, and Birt (2003). Participants viewed emotional visual images as stimuli, and were then asked if there was a large animal in the scene. Negative images were associated with an increased susceptibility to misinformation by 40% over positive and neutral images. Similarly, Porter et al. (2008) asked participants whether they could recall 20 ‘‘widely publicized’’ public events that were positively or negatively valanced. Half of the events were actually fictitious. The findings indicated that more than twice as many participants falsely recognized a bogus negative event (90%) compared to a bogus positive event (42%). Note, however, that this account predicts a bias in the opposite direction of the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle, with more false alarms for negatives than positives.
	Porter et al. (2008) explained their findings and the PNE hypothesis as the result of an evolutionary adaptation. They argue that negative events should be recalled better over time than neutral or other emotional events, in order to avoid or deal with them in the future (Porter & Peace, 2007). Given that it is normally adaptive to incorporate relevant information concerning negative events from others deemed trustworthy (the researchers, for example), this leads to an increased positive response bias for negative events. An alternative explanation is based on the findings of a series of studies Paz and colleagues (Schechtman, Laufer, & Paz, 2010; Laufer & Paz, 2012; Resnik, Sobel N, & Paz, 2011). They demonstrated that individuals tend to show more greater generalization for negative cues than for positive cues. For example in Schechtman et al. (2010) participants responded to a tone that was farther away from an aversive conditioned tone, compared to an equivalent rewarding tone. Therefore, participants may have more false alarms for losses due to overgeneralization of cues presented during the recognition task.  
Still, as mentioned above, it could be that Porter et al.’s (2008) findings might be due to specific properties of the selected events, such as dissimilarities between events. Moreover, the discrepancy between the findings of Porter et al. (2008) and the Ortony et al. (1983) puzzle suggests that additional evidence needs to be collected. To examine the effect of valence on false alarms in a setting with relatively symmetric objective gains and losses, we used a decisions-from-experience task (Rakow & Newell, 2010; Erev & Haruvy, 2015), in which an individual’s gains and losses are the positive and negative events. Gains and losses were counter-balanced creating an objective symmetry in the distribution of events. In three studies, we found evidence for increased false alarm rates in losses (negative valence stimuli), compared to gains.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: IV: Valence (loss: negative numbers, gain: positive numbers) – within-subject variable.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
False-alarms rate: calculated as the number of items participants incorrectly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test, although it was not) divided by the number of “new” items (i.e., in the memory task – items that were not seen before in the gambling task). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses.
Hits rate: calculated as the number of items participants correctly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants correctly report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test) divided by the number of “old” items (i.e., four items). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses
Both rates range 0 to 1.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: Moderator: Filler task (Anagrams: an anagram task will be performed between the gambling and recognition tasks, None: Participants will perform the recognition task right after the gambling task) – between-subject variable.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: If Sphericity in the ANOVA test is violated (Machuly's test), proper DF will be used (e.g., Greenhouse–Geisser)
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
The experiment will be programmed using the oTree platform (Chen, Schonger, & Wickens, 2016). The gambling task involves making 64 repeated selections between two virtual buttons labeled “Bet” and “Skip”. Upon choosing either button, the payoff for the given trial will be presented above the two buttons. Choosing “Bet” implies that the payoff is realized (i.e., added to the participants’ tally which determined their take-home amount), while choosing “Skip” implied that the payoff is  not realized. Following each selection, payoffs are drawn from one of the following two sets: [2, 8, 51, 87, -3, -6, -28, -96], or [-2, -8, -51, -87, 3, 6, 28, 96]. These two sets are identical with the exception that gains in one sets are converted to losses in the other and vice versa. The expected value of the lottery is either slightly negative (set 1) or positive (set 2). Before beginning the task each participant is randomly assigned to one of the two sets, and this assignment remains constant throughout the task. Each item is presented eight times throughout the gambling task in random order (i.e., payoff sets presented above are duplicated eight times for a total of 64 items, and then randomly shuffled for each participant).
Participants will receive no prior information about the payoff distributions or the number of trials. They are told that their task is to choose “Bet” or “Skip” on each trial, and that “Bet” outcomes are added to or subtracted from their final payoff, while "Skip" outcomes are not. Participants are also informed of the conversion rate for the outcomes (1000 points = $1), and that either way they would not earn more than $2 nor less than $1. Half of the participants will perform a filler task, in which they have two minutes to solve a set of fifteen anagrams. Subsequently, the experiment automatically continues to a surprise recognition task.
In the recognition task participants were presented with 20 numbers, including the 8 outcomes and an additional 12 numbers that were not presented in the gambling task: [17, 26, 4, 18, 9, 38, 92,16,46, 73, 5,7]. They will then be asked to report for each of the  20 numbers if it was (1) presented in the gambling task as a gain, (2) presented in the gambling task as a loss, (3) wasn’t presented at the gambling task at all. All 20 numbers will be presented in the same webpage and a combo-box next to each of the numbers will be used for the report. Their order will be randomized per participant.
Participants will be paid as follows: $1.2 for participation (completing the tasks), extra $0.2 for performing the Anagrams task (i.e., participants in the longer version of the experiment which includes the Anagrams task, will be rewarded with $0.2) and a bonus contingent on their performance as described above.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
The calculation of both IVs was described in the design section as follows:
False-alarms rate: calculated as the number of items participants incorrectly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test, although it was not) divided by the number of “new” items (i.e., in the memory task – items that were not seen before in the gambling task). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses.
Hits rate: calculated as the number of items participants correctly categorized as “old” (i.e., participants correctly report that the item appeared in the gambling task prior to the memory test) divided by the number of “old” items (i.e., four items). This rate will be calculated separately for gains and losses
Both rates range 0 to 1.

We will conduct two mixed-effect ANOVAs, one for each DV (H1: False-alarm rate, H2: Hit rate). The within-subject IV will be valence, and between-subject moderator is the presence of an Anagrams task (yes/no).
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: We restrict participation to individuals who are USA residents and has a 95% approval rate of previous works submitted to MTurk.
Based on the previous studies we ran and financial constraints, we plan to collect 230 participants (the largest sample size out among the three previous studies).
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Exclusion Criteria:
-	Participants who will not complete all 64 trials and the recognition task will not be included in the analysis. 
-	Participant who will fail the attention check (i.e., will not follow the instruction to write “thanks” in the first instructions page) or will fail a CAPTCHA test, will not be able to participate in the experiment (i.e., the experiment will stop and they will not be able to continue).
-	Outliers removal: participants who mark all items as either “old gains” or “old losses” in the recognition task will be removed from all analyses.

attributes.title: Attention Bias and Expectancy Biases in Phylogenetic and Ontogenetic Stimuli

q1.value: Attention Bias and Expectancy Biases in Phylogenetic and Ontogenetic Stimuli

q3.value:
One core characteristic of phobia is a cognitive bias towards the feared object/situation. Two main biases are attention and expectancy biases.  In our previous work (Abado, Sagi, Silber, de Houwer, Aue and Okon-Singer, Under review; Aue, Guex, Chauvigné and Okon-Singer, 2013), we have studied the relationship between attention and expectancy biases. We did so by manipulating participants’ expectancies of encountering certain types of stimuli - threatening (spiders) and non-threatening (birds) - among an array of neutral stimuli (butterflies), with an intricate background, thus establishing a causal relationship. First, we found that expectancy cues had an impact on reactions to birds. In contrast, the (same) cues had no impact on reactions to spiders, in both high spider fearful and low spider fearful participants. In addition, reaction times (RTs) to spiders were overall faster than reactions to birds. Thus, robust attention bias toward spiders, but not toward birds, was found among low and high fearful participants. However, when these phylogenetic stimuli (spiders, birds and butterflies) were replaced with ontogenetic stimuli (guns, mobile phones and staplers), this attention bias was not found toward guns (Abado et al. Under review). Hence, one could conclude that spiders receive prioritized processing due their evolutionary importance (Seligman, 1971), while more modern stimuli (i.e. guns) do not (Öhman et al., 1975., 1976). However, this interpretation does not take into account visual factors, which differed between the two experiments. While on Aue et al. (2013) phylogenetic stimuli appeared on complex natural backgrounds, on Abado et al. (under review), ontogenetic objects appeared on clean white background. Thus, this difference in visual factors could be a source of variance in attention bias. 
As there mixed findings in the literature regarding the difference, or lack thereof, between phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli, the present study has two aims: first, to clarify the existence, or lack thereof, of attention bias toward ontogenetic stimuli. This be accomplished by directly comparing responses between ontogenetic and phylogenetic stimuli, under the same conditions. Second, the present study aims at examining the role of visual factors in attention bias. While white backgrounds may seem sterile, articificial and out of context, complex backgrounds (i.e. spiders, birds, and butterflies in nature; guns, phones, and staplers in hands) may provide realistic context and ecological validity. Thus, visual factors (i.e. background) will be controlled while attention bias is measured. To this aim, we will employ a task we have developed and replicated in several studies in the past (e.g., Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), and use phylogenetic stimuli (spiders, birds and butterflies) as well as ontogenetic stimuli (guns, mobile phones and staplers). These stimuli will be presented on a white background or on a complex background. Thus, there will be four between-subjects groups. RTs and accuracy rates will be compared directly between the two different background conditions in order to examine the effects of the visual factors. In addition, participants will be asked to fill out 4 questionnaires: Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), State Anxiety Inventory (STI), Fear of Spiders Questionnaire (FSQ), and Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale (IOU). In addition to the FSQ, participants will answer 3 questions from Origin of Phobia Questionnaire (OPQ) and 8 questions regarding perceived disgust, dangerousness, unpredictability and uncontrollability of spiders. A-priori and a-posteriori expectancy bias of encountering the threatening targets will also be measured. Lastly, in order to better quantify the threat value of each stimulus and in order to understand why attention bias was previously found toward phones, participants will be asked to rate the pleasantness and unpleasantness of each type of stimulus post-experimentally. To conclude, the present study is a control study, meant to clarify the results of previous studies and to examine the role of intervening factors, such as valence, visual features (i.e. background) and indirect comparisons.

q4.value:
1.	Main analysis of RT and accuracy:  We expect to find a triple interaction between stimulus type × cue × target, such that the interaction between cue and target will differ between ontogenetic and phylogenetic groups. In the phylogenetic group, we expect to find a replication of previous results (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward bird targets, and not toward spider targets (i.e. threatening targets). In other words, RT and accuracy toward spider targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In the ontogenetic group, we similarly expect to find a replication of previous results (Abado et al. Unpublished), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward phone targets (i.e. neutral targets), and not toward gun targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward phone targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In addition, based on previous findings, we do not expect to find attention bias toward guns. We also expect a replication of these results in the new conditions (i.e. phones/guns on a complex background and spiders/birds on a white background). As this is a control experiment for previous studies which presented different stimuli on different backgrounds, we predict no effect of the background, thus supporting prioritized processing of spiders in the phylogenetic group. Thus, our main hypothesis is the prioritized processing of spiders and the interaction between cue and target in both phylogenetic backgrounds, and our secondary hypothesis is regarding attention bias toward phones (i.e. interaction between cue and target in both ontogenetic backgrounds).
2.	Questionnaires: BDI, STAI (state), FSQ and IOU will be included. BDI will be used for exclusion only. STAI (state), FSQ and IOU will be used as covariates. As the sample will be random, we expect that most participants will exhibit low to medium levels in all questionnaires. Therefore, we only expect a small-size correlations between IOU/STAI (state) and the interaction (cue x target) effects in all groups. Similarly, in the phylogenetic group, we expect a small-size correlation between FSQ and the cue-target interaction. 
3.	A-priori expectancy and post experimental questionnaire: as previous studies have found that there is equal a-priori bias toward phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli regardless of fear level (Kennedey, Rapee and Mazurski, 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), we expect a replication of these findings. Thus, although each target appears equally often, we expect participants to overestimate the appearance of threatening stimuli (i.e.to choose a probability of over 50%). Additionally, in these same studies (Kennedey et al., 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), a-posteriori bias found only toward phylogenetic stimuli and among high-fear participants. As we will recruit a random sample of participants, we expect that most of them will be low-fearful, and thus we expect a-posteriori bias to be equal in both phylogenetic and ontogenetic groups, and that it will be lower than the a-priori bias.
This question would ask participants if they felt that they have reacted faster to a specific targets. In the case of the phylogenetic group, we expect that participants will explicitly choose “yes, I responded faster to spider targets compared to bird targets”. Thus, as fear is characterized by explicit irrational beliefs, we believe that participants will be able to acknowledge that they react faster toward spiders, compared to birds (Arntz et al., 1993). In the ontogenetic group, we expect one of two findings: as previous studies (Abado et al., unpublished) have found a bias toward phones, participants might similarly acknowledge this bias. However, as attention might be drawn toward phones for different reasons than for spiders, participants might not be able to acknowledge this bias. Regarding the manipulation check question, it is predicted that all participants will correctly indicate on the scale that the verbal cues were mostly valid. In other words, the mean of this measure is expected to be over 50%, with no differences across the four between-subject groups.
Regarding the questions regarding phobic learning, and perceived disgust, danger, uncontrollability and unpredictability, we expect that the latter 4 dimensions will reduce unexplained variance to the expected attention bias toward spiders found in the phylogenetic groups. Regarding phobic learning, the questions are exploratory and we have no specific hypotheses for this dimension. 
4.	Post experimental valence measure: As our previous studies have found an attention bias toward mobile phones in an ontogenetic experiment, we expect that mobile phones will receive mixed responses (i.e. both pleasant and unpleasant), while guns will be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all. Staplers are expected to be neutral on both scales. In the phylogenetic group, we expect spiders to be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all, while birds and butterflies are mildly pleasant and not unpleasant at all.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study will use a mixed design, with 2 between-subject factors (type of background: white/complex; type of stimulus: phylogenetic/ontogenetic) and 2 within-subjects factors (type of cue: threatening/neutral; type of target: threatening/neutral).
Questionnaires: before the beginning of the experimental paradigm, participants will be asked to fill the State Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, Gorsuch, Lushene, Vagg, and Jacobs, 1983), Beck Depression Inventory (Beck, Ward, Mendelson, Mock, and Erbaugh, 1961), and the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale – short form (Carleton, Norton, and Asmundson, 2007). Following the experiment, participants will be asked to fill the Fear of Spiders Questionnaire (Szymanski and O'Donohue, 1995). Following the FSQ, participants will be asked to answer 3 questions regarding the origin of their fear of spiders (vicarious learning, conditioning and negative information; Öst and Hugdahl, 1981; each question has 3 possible answers: "yes", "no", "I don't know"), 2 questions regarding perceived disgust of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), 2 questions regarding perceived dangerousness of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), 2 questions regarding perceived uncontrollability of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), and 2 questions regarding perceived unpredictability of spiders (Arntz, Lavy, Van den Berg, and Van Rijsoort, 1993). The answers for the latter 4 dimensions (i.e. 8 questions) will be rated on a scale ranging from 1-7 ("strongly disagree" to "strongly agree"). 
Visual search array: pictures for the spiders/complex background condition will be the exact same pictures that were used in previous studies (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018; spider pictures taken from Dan-Glauser and Scherer, 2011). Pictures for the guns/white background condition will be the exact same pictures that were used in a previous study (Abado et al. Unpublished). Pictures for the rest of the condition (i.e. spiders/white background and guns/complex background condition were collected from the internet. For the latter condition, four pictures were taken from the International Affective Picture System (Lang, Bradley, and Cuthbert, 2008) and one picture from the Open Affective Standardized Imaged Set (Kurdi, Lozano, and Banaji, 2017). For each condition, 30 threatening pictures (i.e. guns or spiders), 30 neutral targets (i.e. phones or birds) and 100 neutral distractors (i.e. staplers or butterflies) were collected. For each condition, the three categories of pictures were matched for contrast and luminance. Each picture (distractors or target) has an equal probability of appearing anywhere in the 9 possible locations.
Experimental paradigm: participants will first take part in 20 practice trials, then perform three blocks, each consisting of 101 trials, with 2 breaks in between. After practice and before the experiment begins, participants will asked to rate, using visual analogue scale (VAS) ranging from 1%-100%, the probability of encountering the threatening target throughout the experiment. This measure will reflect participants’ a-priori expectancy of encountering the fearful stimulus. Then, the experiment will begin. During the experimental paradigm, each trial will begin with a fixation point (500 ms), after which the probability of the target stimulus type in the next trial (expectancy cue- either 90% gun/spider or 90% phone/bird) will appear for 1,000 ms. Then, another fixation will appear (500 ms), followed by the search array (2,000 ms or until response), consisting of 8 pictures of staplers/butterflies, and one picture of either a phone/bird or a gun/spider. Several trials will have no target, meaning they will include 9 pictures of staplers or 9 pictures of butterflies. Participants will be instructed to respond as quickly and as accurately as possible and to determine the category of the target stimuli by pressing the P key for gun/spider and Q key for phone/bird targets (counterbalanced) or SPACE bar for no target. The congruency rate between cues and targets is 71%, and 5% of trials are catch trials (i.e. no target). The experimental paradigm takes 25 minutes to complete. 
Post experimental questionnaires: following the experimental paradigm, participants will be asked to answer three questions: (a) they will be asked to indicate if they felt, during the experiment, that they reacted faster to a specific target (three counterbalanced choices); (b) using a VAS that is identical to the one used to measure a-priori expectancies, participants will asked to rate the probability of threatening targets that they have encountered throughout the experiment. This measure will reflect participants’ a-posteriori expectancy. These two questions are counterbalanced and they are meant to reflect explicit awareness of attention bias and a-posteriori expectancy bias. The third question is a manipulation check; participants will be asked to indicate if they felt that the cues truly predicted the target (71% of trials are congruent). Participants will be presented with a VAS and asked to indicate the congruency rate on it, ranging from 0% to 100% (i.e. “not predictive at all” to “very predictive”). Lastly, in order to rule out valence as an intervening factors, participants will be presented with 30 random pictures from the experiment (10 from each category – threatening target, neutral target and distractors) and for each picture they will be asked to indicate how pleasant and how unpleasant it is, each on a scale from 0-8  (Kron, Goldstein, Lee, Gardhouse, and Anderson). Each picture will appear for 4 seconds, followed by the two scales (counterbalanced).
When done, participants will be thanked, paid or credited and be given a form of possible psychological treatment centers.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: As there are four groups, participants will be randomly assigned to each group, with an equal number of participants in each group (i.e. 30). They will be recruited via the SONA system, and the description will state the length of the experiment, the credit/payment given in exchange for participation, and a brief description of the procedure. In addition, similar ads for recruitment will be placed on social networks and university websites. Inclusion criteria: normal or corrected-to normal vision. Exclusion criteria (post-experimental): for each participant, if the average of either dependent measure (i.e. RT or accuracy) is larger than 2.5 SD in absolute terms, as calculated for each participant in comparison with the entire group average. In addition, participants with severe depression (BDI score over 28) will also be excluded.

q13.value: Overall, 120 participants will participate in the study in exchange for course credit or payment, as instructed at the University of Haifa Department of Psychology website.

q14.value:
Sample size was determined using the software G*Power (version 3.1.9.4; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, and Lang, 2009), with a medium effect size (0.06). This was based on the planned main analysis of 2 within factors (target: threatening/neural, cue: threatening/neutral) and 2 between factors (background: white/complex) and stimulus type (phylogenetic/ontogenetic).
Accordingly, 92 participants are needed to reach standard power (0.8) and alpha probability error (0.05). We have decided to round up (from 23 participants per group to 30 participants per group), in order to counterbalance versions and to account for excluded participants.

question.value: We will manipulate 2 between-subjects variables: type of background (white or complex) and type of stimulus (phylogenetic or ontogenetic). In addition, 2 within-subjects variables will be manipulated: type of cue (threatening or neutral, i.e. spiders and birds in the phylogenetic group of guns and phone in the ontogenetic group) and type of target (similarly to the cue, threatening or neutral).

We will measure accuracy rates and reaction time for correct responses. In addition, participants will fill out the State Anxiety Inventory, Beck Depression Inventory, Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, and Fear of Spiders Questionnaire. A-priori and a-posteriori expectancy will also be measured. These will be quantified using a visual analogue scale (VAS), each time asking participants how often they expect to encounter the threatening stimulus (0%-100%) before the experiment, and similarly asking them how much they have encountered the threatening stimulus (0%-100%) after the experiment. 
Perceived disgust, dangerousness, uncontrollablility and unpredictability of spiders and questions from the Phobic Origin Questionnaire (POQ) questions will be included. The first 4 dimensions will be rated on a 1-7 scale ("strongly disagree" to "strongly agree"), while POQ questions have 3 categorical answers ("yes", "no", "I don't know").
In addition, participants will be asked to rate the valence of 30 random pictures (i.e. pleasantness and unpleasantness scales), and if they felt that they responded faster to a specific target. Each scale will be rated on a 0-8 scale ("not pleasant/unpleasant at all" to "very pleasant/unpleasant").

Attention bias toward spiders = RT toward bird targets minus RT toward spider targets (regardless of cue). The same index will be applied to phones in the ontogenetic group.
Facilitation of cue toward spider targets = RT toward trials of bird cue-spider target minus spider cue-spider target. The same index will be applied to phones in the ontogenetic group.

1.	Main analysis of RT and accuracy: A 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted on the RT and accuracy rate data, with stimulus type (phylogenetic, ontogenetic) and background (complex, white) as the between-subject factors and cue (bird, spider in phylogenetic; phone, gun in ontogenetic) and target (bird, spider in phylogenetic; phone, gun in ontogenetic) as the within-subject factors.
We expect to find a triple interaction between stimulus type × cue × target, such that the interaction between cue and target will differ between ontogenetic and phylogenetic groups. In the phylogenetic group, we expect to find a replication of previous results (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward bird targets, and not toward spider targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward spider targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In the ontogenetic group, we similarly expect to find a replication of previous results (Abado et al. Unpublished), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward phone targets, and not toward gun targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward phone targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In addition, based on previous findings, we do not expect to find attention bias toward guns.
2.	Questionnaires: BDI will be used for exclusion, while FSQ, STAI (state) and IOU will enter two exploratory hierarchical regression models for each calculated index (attention bias and facilitation). The predictors will include stimulus type (phylogenetic /ontogenetic), background type (complex/white), and the three questionnaires, as well as the interaction of each questionnaire with the two between-subject variables.
3.	A-priori VAS and post experimental questionnaire: as previous studies have found that there is equal a-priori bias toward phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli regardless of fear level (Kennedey, Rapee and Mazurski, 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), we expect a replication of these findings. Thus, although each target appears equally often, we expect participants to overestimate the appearance of threatening stimuli (i.e.to choose a probability of over 50%). Additionally, in these same studies (Kennedey et al., 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), a-posteriori bias found only toward phylogenetic stimuli and among high-fear participants. As we will recruit a random sample of participants, we expect that most of them will be low-fearful, and thus we expect a-posteriori bias to be equal in both phylogenetic and ontogenetic groups, and that it will be lower than the a-priori bias.
Non-parametric tests will be conducted on the data from the question regarding RT. This question would ask participants if they felt that they have reacted faster to a specific targets. In the case of the phylogenetic group, we expect that participants will explicitly choose “yes, I responded faster to spider targets compared to bird targets”. Thus, as fear is characterized by explicit irrational beliefs, we believe that participants will be able to acknowledge that they react faster toward spiders, compared to birds (Arntz et al., 1993). In the ontogenetic group, we expect one of two findings: as previous studies (Abado et al., unpublished) have found a bias toward phones, participants might similarly acknowledge this bias. However, as attention might be drawn toward phones for different reasons than for spiders, participants might not be able to acknowledge this bias. Regarding the manipulation check question, it is predicted that all participants will correctly indicate on the scale that the verbal cues were mostly valid. In other words, the mean of this measure is expected to be over 50%, with no differences across the four between-subject groups.
Regarding the questions regarding phobic learning, and perceived disgust, danger, uncontrollability and unpredictability, we expect that the latter 4 dimensions will reduce unexplained variance to the expected attention bias toward spiders found in the phylogenetic groups. Regarding phobic learning, the questions are exploratory and we have no specific hypotheses for this dimension. 
4.	Post experimental valence measure: A 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted on valence data, with stimulus type  (phylogenetic, ontogenetic) and background (complex, white) as the between-subject factors and scale type (pleasant, unpleasant) as the within-subject factors. As our previous studies have found an attention bias toward mobile phones in an ontogenetic experiment, we expect that mobile phones will receive mixed responses (i.e. both pleasant and unpleasant), while guns will be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all. Staplers are expected to be neutral on both scales. In the phylogenetic group, we expect spiders to be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all, while birds and butterflies are mildly pleasant and not unpleasant at all.

q22.value: After the collection of data, outlier participants will be excluded, based on their RT and accuracy measures. Participants with over +-2.5 SD, compared to the general average of their group, will be excluded. In addition, participants with severe levels of depression (BDI over 28) will also be excluded.

registration_responses.q1: Attention Bias and Expectancy Biases in Phylogenetic and Ontogenetic Stimuli
registration_responses.q3:
One core characteristic of phobia is a cognitive bias towards the feared object/situation. Two main biases are attention and expectancy biases.  In our previous work (Abado, Sagi, Silber, de Houwer, Aue and Okon-Singer, Under review; Aue, Guex, Chauvigné and Okon-Singer, 2013), we have studied the relationship between attention and expectancy biases. We did so by manipulating participants’ expectancies of encountering certain types of stimuli - threatening (spiders) and non-threatening (birds) - among an array of neutral stimuli (butterflies), with an intricate background, thus establishing a causal relationship. First, we found that expectancy cues had an impact on reactions to birds. In contrast, the (same) cues had no impact on reactions to spiders, in both high spider fearful and low spider fearful participants. In addition, reaction times (RTs) to spiders were overall faster than reactions to birds. Thus, robust attention bias toward spiders, but not toward birds, was found among low and high fearful participants. However, when these phylogenetic stimuli (spiders, birds and butterflies) were replaced with ontogenetic stimuli (guns, mobile phones and staplers), this attention bias was not found toward guns (Abado et al. Under review). Hence, one could conclude that spiders receive prioritized processing due their evolutionary importance (Seligman, 1971), while more modern stimuli (i.e. guns) do not (Öhman et al., 1975., 1976). However, this interpretation does not take into account visual factors, which differed between the two experiments. While on Aue et al. (2013) phylogenetic stimuli appeared on complex natural backgrounds, on Abado et al. (under review), ontogenetic objects appeared on clean white background. Thus, this difference in visual factors could be a source of variance in attention bias. 
As there mixed findings in the literature regarding the difference, or lack thereof, between phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli, the present study has two aims: first, to clarify the existence, or lack thereof, of attention bias toward ontogenetic stimuli. This be accomplished by directly comparing responses between ontogenetic and phylogenetic stimuli, under the same conditions. Second, the present study aims at examining the role of visual factors in attention bias. While white backgrounds may seem sterile, articificial and out of context, complex backgrounds (i.e. spiders, birds, and butterflies in nature; guns, phones, and staplers in hands) may provide realistic context and ecological validity. Thus, visual factors (i.e. background) will be controlled while attention bias is measured. To this aim, we will employ a task we have developed and replicated in several studies in the past (e.g., Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), and use phylogenetic stimuli (spiders, birds and butterflies) as well as ontogenetic stimuli (guns, mobile phones and staplers). These stimuli will be presented on a white background or on a complex background. Thus, there will be four between-subjects groups. RTs and accuracy rates will be compared directly between the two different background conditions in order to examine the effects of the visual factors. In addition, participants will be asked to fill out 4 questionnaires: Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), State Anxiety Inventory (STI), Fear of Spiders Questionnaire (FSQ), and Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale (IOU). In addition to the FSQ, participants will answer 3 questions from Origin of Phobia Questionnaire (OPQ) and 8 questions regarding perceived disgust, dangerousness, unpredictability and uncontrollability of spiders. A-priori and a-posteriori expectancy bias of encountering the threatening targets will also be measured. Lastly, in order to better quantify the threat value of each stimulus and in order to understand why attention bias was previously found toward phones, participants will be asked to rate the pleasantness and unpleasantness of each type of stimulus post-experimentally. To conclude, the present study is a control study, meant to clarify the results of previous studies and to examine the role of intervening factors, such as valence, visual features (i.e. background) and indirect comparisons.
registration_responses.q4:
1.	Main analysis of RT and accuracy:  We expect to find a triple interaction between stimulus type × cue × target, such that the interaction between cue and target will differ between ontogenetic and phylogenetic groups. In the phylogenetic group, we expect to find a replication of previous results (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward bird targets, and not toward spider targets (i.e. threatening targets). In other words, RT and accuracy toward spider targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In the ontogenetic group, we similarly expect to find a replication of previous results (Abado et al. Unpublished), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward phone targets (i.e. neutral targets), and not toward gun targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward phone targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In addition, based on previous findings, we do not expect to find attention bias toward guns. We also expect a replication of these results in the new conditions (i.e. phones/guns on a complex background and spiders/birds on a white background). As this is a control experiment for previous studies which presented different stimuli on different backgrounds, we predict no effect of the background, thus supporting prioritized processing of spiders in the phylogenetic group. Thus, our main hypothesis is the prioritized processing of spiders and the interaction between cue and target in both phylogenetic backgrounds, and our secondary hypothesis is regarding attention bias toward phones (i.e. interaction between cue and target in both ontogenetic backgrounds).
2.	Questionnaires: BDI, STAI (state), FSQ and IOU will be included. BDI will be used for exclusion only. STAI (state), FSQ and IOU will be used as covariates. As the sample will be random, we expect that most participants will exhibit low to medium levels in all questionnaires. Therefore, we only expect a small-size correlations between IOU/STAI (state) and the interaction (cue x target) effects in all groups. Similarly, in the phylogenetic group, we expect a small-size correlation between FSQ and the cue-target interaction. 
3.	A-priori expectancy and post experimental questionnaire: as previous studies have found that there is equal a-priori bias toward phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli regardless of fear level (Kennedey, Rapee and Mazurski, 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), we expect a replication of these findings. Thus, although each target appears equally often, we expect participants to overestimate the appearance of threatening stimuli (i.e.to choose a probability of over 50%). Additionally, in these same studies (Kennedey et al., 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), a-posteriori bias found only toward phylogenetic stimuli and among high-fear participants. As we will recruit a random sample of participants, we expect that most of them will be low-fearful, and thus we expect a-posteriori bias to be equal in both phylogenetic and ontogenetic groups, and that it will be lower than the a-priori bias.
This question would ask participants if they felt that they have reacted faster to a specific targets. In the case of the phylogenetic group, we expect that participants will explicitly choose “yes, I responded faster to spider targets compared to bird targets”. Thus, as fear is characterized by explicit irrational beliefs, we believe that participants will be able to acknowledge that they react faster toward spiders, compared to birds (Arntz et al., 1993). In the ontogenetic group, we expect one of two findings: as previous studies (Abado et al., unpublished) have found a bias toward phones, participants might similarly acknowledge this bias. However, as attention might be drawn toward phones for different reasons than for spiders, participants might not be able to acknowledge this bias. Regarding the manipulation check question, it is predicted that all participants will correctly indicate on the scale that the verbal cues were mostly valid. In other words, the mean of this measure is expected to be over 50%, with no differences across the four between-subject groups.
Regarding the questions regarding phobic learning, and perceived disgust, danger, uncontrollability and unpredictability, we expect that the latter 4 dimensions will reduce unexplained variance to the expected attention bias toward spiders found in the phylogenetic groups. Regarding phobic learning, the questions are exploratory and we have no specific hypotheses for this dimension. 
4.	Post experimental valence measure: As our previous studies have found an attention bias toward mobile phones in an ontogenetic experiment, we expect that mobile phones will receive mixed responses (i.e. both pleasant and unpleasant), while guns will be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all. Staplers are expected to be neutral on both scales. In the phylogenetic group, we expect spiders to be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all, while birds and butterflies are mildly pleasant and not unpleasant at all.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q13: Overall, 120 participants will participate in the study in exchange for course credit or payment, as instructed at the University of Haifa Department of Psychology website.
registration_responses.q14:
Sample size was determined using the software G*Power (version 3.1.9.4; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, and Lang, 2009), with a medium effect size (0.06). This was based on the planned main analysis of 2 within factors (target: threatening/neural, cue: threatening/neutral) and 2 between factors (background: white/complex) and stimulus type (phylogenetic/ontogenetic).
Accordingly, 92 participants are needed to reach standard power (0.8) and alpha probability error (0.05). We have decided to round up (from 23 participants per group to 30 participants per group), in order to counterbalance versions and to account for excluded participants.
registration_responses.q22: After the collection of data, outlier participants will be excluded, based on their RT and accuracy measures. Participants with over +-2.5 SD, compared to the general average of their group, will be excluded. In addition, participants with severe levels of depression (BDI over 28) will also be excluded.
registration_responses.q24: Non-parametric tests will be conducted on the data from the question regarding phobic origin (Phobic Origin Questionnaire). The questions are exploratory and we have no specific hypotheses for this dimension. As mentioned earlier, two regression models will also be exploratory, as they include the three questionnaires.
registration_responses.q8.question:
The study will use a mixed design, with 2 between-subject factors (type of background: white/complex; type of stimulus: phylogenetic/ontogenetic) and 2 within-subjects factors (type of cue: threatening/neutral; type of target: threatening/neutral).
Questionnaires: before the beginning of the experimental paradigm, participants will be asked to fill the State Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, Gorsuch, Lushene, Vagg, and Jacobs, 1983), Beck Depression Inventory (Beck, Ward, Mendelson, Mock, and Erbaugh, 1961), and the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale – short form (Carleton, Norton, and Asmundson, 2007). Following the experiment, participants will be asked to fill the Fear of Spiders Questionnaire (Szymanski and O'Donohue, 1995). Following the FSQ, participants will be asked to answer 3 questions regarding the origin of their fear of spiders (vicarious learning, conditioning and negative information; Öst and Hugdahl, 1981; each question has 3 possible answers: "yes", "no", "I don't know"), 2 questions regarding perceived disgust of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), 2 questions regarding perceived dangerousness of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), 2 questions regarding perceived uncontrollability of spiders (Armfield and Mattiske, 1996), and 2 questions regarding perceived unpredictability of spiders (Arntz, Lavy, Van den Berg, and Van Rijsoort, 1993). The answers for the latter 4 dimensions (i.e. 8 questions) will be rated on a scale ranging from 1-7 ("strongly disagree" to "strongly agree"). 
Visual search array: pictures for the spiders/complex background condition will be the exact same pictures that were used in previous studies (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018; spider pictures taken from Dan-Glauser and Scherer, 2011). Pictures for the guns/white background condition will be the exact same pictures that were used in a previous study (Abado et al. Unpublished). Pictures for the rest of the condition (i.e. spiders/white background and guns/complex background condition were collected from the internet. For the latter condition, four pictures were taken from the International Affective Picture System (Lang, Bradley, and Cuthbert, 2008) and one picture from the Open Affective Standardized Imaged Set (Kurdi, Lozano, and Banaji, 2017). For each condition, 30 threatening pictures (i.e. guns or spiders), 30 neutral targets (i.e. phones or birds) and 100 neutral distractors (i.e. staplers or butterflies) were collected. For each condition, the three categories of pictures were matched for contrast and luminance. Each picture (distractors or target) has an equal probability of appearing anywhere in the 9 possible locations.
Experimental paradigm: participants will first take part in 20 practice trials, then perform three blocks, each consisting of 101 trials, with 2 breaks in between. After practice and before the experiment begins, participants will asked to rate, using visual analogue scale (VAS) ranging from 1%-100%, the probability of encountering the threatening target throughout the experiment. This measure will reflect participants’ a-priori expectancy of encountering the fearful stimulus. Then, the experiment will begin. During the experimental paradigm, each trial will begin with a fixation point (500 ms), after which the probability of the target stimulus type in the next trial (expectancy cue- either 90% gun/spider or 90% phone/bird) will appear for 1,000 ms. Then, another fixation will appear (500 ms), followed by the search array (2,000 ms or until response), consisting of 8 pictures of staplers/butterflies, and one picture of either a phone/bird or a gun/spider. Several trials will have no target, meaning they will include 9 pictures of staplers or 9 pictures of butterflies. Participants will be instructed to respond as quickly and as accurately as possible and to determine the category of the target stimuli by pressing the P key for gun/spider and Q key for phone/bird targets (counterbalanced) or SPACE bar for no target. The congruency rate between cues and targets is 71%, and 5% of trials are catch trials (i.e. no target). The experimental paradigm takes 25 minutes to complete. 
Post experimental questionnaires: following the experimental paradigm, participants will be asked to answer three questions: (a) they will be asked to indicate if they felt, during the experiment, that they reacted faster to a specific target (three counterbalanced choices); (b) using a VAS that is identical to the one used to measure a-priori expectancies, participants will asked to rate the probability of threatening targets that they have encountered throughout the experiment. This measure will reflect participants’ a-posteriori expectancy. These two questions are counterbalanced and they are meant to reflect explicit awareness of attention bias and a-posteriori expectancy bias. The third question is a manipulation check; participants will be asked to indicate if they felt that the cues truly predicted the target (71% of trials are congruent). Participants will be presented with a VAS and asked to indicate the congruency rate on it, ranging from 0% to 100% (i.e. “not predictive at all” to “very predictive”). Lastly, in order to rule out valence as an intervening factors, participants will be presented with 30 random pictures from the experiment (10 from each category – threatening target, neutral target and distractors) and for each picture they will be asked to indicate how pleasant and how unpleasant it is, each on a scale from 0-8  (Kron, Goldstein, Lee, Gardhouse, and Anderson). Each picture will appear for 4 seconds, followed by the two scales (counterbalanced).
When done, participants will be thanked, paid or credited and be given a form of possible psychological treatment centers.
registration_responses.q12.question: As there are four groups, participants will be randomly assigned to each group, with an equal number of participants in each group (i.e. 30). They will be recruited via the SONA system, and the description will state the length of the experiment, the credit/payment given in exchange for participation, and a brief description of the procedure. In addition, similar ads for recruitment will be placed on social networks and university websites. Inclusion criteria: normal or corrected-to normal vision. Exclusion criteria (post-experimental): for each participant, if the average of either dependent measure (i.e. RT or accuracy) is larger than 2.5 SD in absolute terms, as calculated for each participant in comparison with the entire group average. In addition, participants with severe depression (BDI score over 28) will also be excluded.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate 2 between-subjects variables: type of background (white or complex) and type of stimulus (phylogenetic or ontogenetic). In addition, 2 within-subjects variables will be manipulated: type of cue (threatening or neutral, i.e. spiders and birds in the phylogenetic group of guns and phone in the ontogenetic group) and type of target (similarly to the cue, threatening or neutral).
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure accuracy rates and reaction time for correct responses. In addition, participants will fill out the State Anxiety Inventory, Beck Depression Inventory, Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, and Fear of Spiders Questionnaire. A-priori and a-posteriori expectancy will also be measured. These will be quantified using a visual analogue scale (VAS), each time asking participants how often they expect to encounter the threatening stimulus (0%-100%) before the experiment, and similarly asking them how much they have encountered the threatening stimulus (0%-100%) after the experiment. 
Perceived disgust, dangerousness, uncontrollablility and unpredictability of spiders and questions from the Phobic Origin Questionnaire (POQ) questions will be included. The first 4 dimensions will be rated on a 1-7 scale ("strongly disagree" to "strongly agree"), while POQ questions have 3 categorical answers ("yes", "no", "I don't know").
In addition, participants will be asked to rate the valence of 30 random pictures (i.e. pleasantness and unpleasantness scales), and if they felt that they responded faster to a specific target. Each scale will be rated on a 0-8 scale ("not pleasant/unpleasant at all" to "very pleasant/unpleasant").
registration_responses.q18.question:
Attention bias toward spiders = RT toward bird targets minus RT toward spider targets (regardless of cue). The same index will be applied to phones in the ontogenetic group.
Facilitation of cue toward spider targets = RT toward trials of bird cue-spider target minus spider cue-spider target. The same index will be applied to phones in the ontogenetic group.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1.	Main analysis of RT and accuracy: A 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted on the RT and accuracy rate data, with stimulus type (phylogenetic, ontogenetic) and background (complex, white) as the between-subject factors and cue (bird, spider in phylogenetic; phone, gun in ontogenetic) and target (bird, spider in phylogenetic; phone, gun in ontogenetic) as the within-subject factors.
We expect to find a triple interaction between stimulus type × cue × target, such that the interaction between cue and target will differ between ontogenetic and phylogenetic groups. In the phylogenetic group, we expect to find a replication of previous results (Aue et al., 2013, 2016, 2018), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward bird targets, and not toward spider targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward spider targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In the ontogenetic group, we similarly expect to find a replication of previous results (Abado et al. Unpublished), such that facilitation of cue will only be found toward phone targets, and not toward gun targets. In other words, RT and accuracy toward phone targets will not differ as a function of the type of cue (valid or invalid). In addition, based on previous findings, we do not expect to find attention bias toward guns.
2.	Questionnaires: BDI will be used for exclusion, while FSQ, STAI (state) and IOU will enter two exploratory hierarchical regression models for each calculated index (attention bias and facilitation). The predictors will include stimulus type (phylogenetic /ontogenetic), background type (complex/white), and the three questionnaires, as well as the interaction of each questionnaire with the two between-subject variables.
3.	A-priori VAS and post experimental questionnaire: as previous studies have found that there is equal a-priori bias toward phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli regardless of fear level (Kennedey, Rapee and Mazurski, 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), we expect a replication of these findings. Thus, although each target appears equally often, we expect participants to overestimate the appearance of threatening stimuli (i.e.to choose a probability of over 50%). Additionally, in these same studies (Kennedey et al., 1996; Mühlberger et al., 2006), a-posteriori bias found only toward phylogenetic stimuli and among high-fear participants. As we will recruit a random sample of participants, we expect that most of them will be low-fearful, and thus we expect a-posteriori bias to be equal in both phylogenetic and ontogenetic groups, and that it will be lower than the a-priori bias.
Non-parametric tests will be conducted on the data from the question regarding RT. This question would ask participants if they felt that they have reacted faster to a specific targets. In the case of the phylogenetic group, we expect that participants will explicitly choose “yes, I responded faster to spider targets compared to bird targets”. Thus, as fear is characterized by explicit irrational beliefs, we believe that participants will be able to acknowledge that they react faster toward spiders, compared to birds (Arntz et al., 1993). In the ontogenetic group, we expect one of two findings: as previous studies (Abado et al., unpublished) have found a bias toward phones, participants might similarly acknowledge this bias. However, as attention might be drawn toward phones for different reasons than for spiders, participants might not be able to acknowledge this bias. Regarding the manipulation check question, it is predicted that all participants will correctly indicate on the scale that the verbal cues were mostly valid. In other words, the mean of this measure is expected to be over 50%, with no differences across the four between-subject groups.
Regarding the questions regarding phobic learning, and perceived disgust, danger, uncontrollability and unpredictability, we expect that the latter 4 dimensions will reduce unexplained variance to the expected attention bias toward spiders found in the phylogenetic groups. Regarding phobic learning, the questions are exploratory and we have no specific hypotheses for this dimension. 
4.	Post experimental valence measure: A 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted on valence data, with stimulus type  (phylogenetic, ontogenetic) and background (complex, white) as the between-subject factors and scale type (pleasant, unpleasant) as the within-subject factors. As our previous studies have found an attention bias toward mobile phones in an ontogenetic experiment, we expect that mobile phones will receive mixed responses (i.e. both pleasant and unpleasant), while guns will be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all. Staplers are expected to be neutral on both scales. In the phylogenetic group, we expect spiders to be wholly unpleasant and not pleasant at all, while birds and butterflies are mildly pleasant and not unpleasant at all.
